headline.main: HOW THE 'LIGHT' FOODS ARE CONQUERING AMERICA

docs.lead_paragraph: SO many new ''light'' products have appeared on the market in recent months that light foods and beverages represent the major growth field in the American food industry. Such items as light canned fruit, light pancake mix, light spaghetti sauce, light salad dressing, light ketchup, light frozen dinners, light wine and light cocoa mix can be found on supermarket shelves. Other light fare - it generally contains about a third fewer calories than comparable products - that is to appear soon includes potato chips, snack foods, fruit drinks and cookies. Industry executives and market analysts predict that the upsurge of light foods, which has been under way for two years, will continue and they venture that when the scramble to offer new products is over, low-calorie foods could constitute up to 10 percent of the $300 billion American food market. ''We certainly see the influx of new products continuing at this pace for a while,'' said Anne Neilson of Arthur D. Little Inc., the industrial research and management consulting concern in Cambridge, Mass. ''I don't think it has peaked yet. Consumers are buying these foods because they are psychologically assuaging. They easily combat any guilt feelings you may have about not going on a strict diet. With light products you eat what you want but convince yourself that you are doing something good.''
